summary: James Angleton was a high-ranking CIA official who is mentioned in several FBI and CIA documents. He served as a key liaison between the CIA and other agencies, including the FBI and Israeli Intelligence. The documents reveal that Angleton provided information to the FBI, particularly concerning Israeli matters, outside of regular CIA channels. To protect his identity and the source of the information, a procedure was established where Angleton was referred to as 'Bureau Informant 100.' The FBI maintained a control file for information received from Angleton, but it was later discontinued as the information was already recorded in separate case files. Angleton's name appears in connection with the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA) request for information, indicating his potential involvement or knowledge related to the JFK assassination investigation. He is also mentioned in connection to CIA mail opening projects.
significance: Angleton's significance in the JFK context stems from his role as a high-ranking CIA official and his connections to intelligence gathering and liaison activities. His name appearing in the HSCA request suggests that he may have been a person of interest during the investigation into the assassination. The documents do not directly implicate him in the assassination, but his position and access to information make him a relevant figure in understanding the broader intelligence landscape surrounding the event.
